section.title: Other Options for Finding Algebraic Antiderivatives

li.p: How does the method of partial fractions enable many rational functions to be antidifferentiated?

How does the method of trigonometric substitutions help us find antiderivatives of functions that may include expressions like \sqrt{a^2-x^2}, a^2 + x^2 , and \sqrt{a^2 + x^2} where a is any real number?

introduction.p: We have learned two antidifferentiation techniques: u-substitution and integration by parts. The former is used to reverse the chain rule, while the latter is used to reverse the product rule. But we have seen that each works only in specialized circumstances. For example, while \int xe^{x^2} \, dx may be evaluated by u-substitution and \int x e^x \, dx by integration by parts, neither method provides a route to evaluate \int e^{x^2} \, dx. In fact, an elementary algebraic antiderivative for e^{x^2} does not exist. No antidifferentiation method will provide us with a simple algebraic formula for a function F(x) that satisfies F'(x) = e^{x^2}.

In this section, our main goals are to identify some classes of functions that can be antidifferentiated, and to learn some methods to do so. We should also recognize that there are many functions for which an algebraic formula for an antiderivative does not exist, and appreciate the role that computing technology can play in finding antiderivatives of other complicated functions.

statement.p:
For each of the indefinite integrals below, decide whether the integral can be evaluated using u-substitution, integration by parts, a combination of the two, or neither.
For integrals for which your answer is affirmative, state the substitution(s) you would use. It is not necessary to actually evaluate any of the integrals completely, unless the integral can be evaluated immediately using a familiar basic antiderivative.
\int x^2 \sin(x^3) \, dx, \int x^2 \sin(x) \, dx, \int \sin(x^3) \, dx, \int x^5 \sin(x^3) \, dx
\int \frac{1}{1+x^2} \, dx, \int \frac{x}{1+x^2} \, dx, \int \frac{2x+3}{1+x^2} \, dx, \int \frac{e^x}{1+(e^x)^2} \, dx,
\int x \ln(x) \, dx, \int \frac{\ln(x)}{x} \, dx, \int \ln(1+x^2) \, dx, \int x\ln(1+x^2) \, dx,
\int x \sqrt{1-x^2} \, dx, \int \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^2}} \, dx, \int \frac{x}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}\, dx, \int \frac{1}{x\sqrt{1-x^2}} \, dx,

li.p: The first integral may be solved by substitution using u = x^3 \ , du = 3x^2 \, dx . The second may be solved using IBP with u = x^2 \ , dv = \sin(x) \, dx The third can not be solved using substitution or IBP. The last one can be solve using a combination. First do a substitution with w = x^3 \ , dw = 3x^2 \, dx to convert the integral to \frac{1}{3} \int w \sin(w) \, dw . This may be solved using IBP with u = w and dv = \sin(w) \, dw.

The first integral can be evaluated by following Table which has antiderivatives of some basic functions. The second integral can be solved using the u -substitution u=1+x^2 \ , du=2x \, dx . This transforms the integral to \frac{1}{2} \int \frac{1}{u} \, du . The third integral requires algebraic manipulation before you can successfully use a substitution. We can evaluate \int \frac{2x+3}{1+x^2} \, dx by recognizing that \frac{2x+3}{1+x^2} =\frac{2x}{1+x^2} + \frac{3}{1+x^2} so we can split the original integral into two integrals. Then, evaluate \int \frac{2x}{1+x^2} \, dx with the substitution u=1+x^2 \ , du=2x \, dx and evaluate \int \frac{3}{1+x^2} \, dx by following Table . The fourth integral can be found by using the substitution u=e^x \ , du=e^x \, dx which transforms the integral to \int \frac{1}{1+u^2} \, du . The antiderivative of \frac{1}{1+u^2} \, du is in Table .

The first integral can be evaluated by using integration by parts with u= \ln(x) and dv=x \, dx . The second integral is evaluated by using the substitution u=\ln(x) \ , du= \frac{1}{x} \, dx . The third integral cannot be solved by only using the methods of integration by parts or substitution. In fact, one solution to evaluate it involves first using integration by parts then using a method called partial fractions. The fourth integral can be evaluated by using both a substitution and integration by parts. First, perform the substitution w=1+x^2 \ , dw= 2x \, dx which transforms the integral to \frac{1}{2} \int \ln(w) \, dw . Integration by parts can be used to evaluate this with u=\ln(w) and dv=dx .

The first integral can be found by using the substitution u=1-x^2 \ , du=-2x \, dx . The second integral can be evaluated by following Table . The third integral can be evaluated by using the substitution u=1-x^2 \ , du=-2x\, dx . The fourth integral cannot be solved with standard substitution, integration by parts, or a combination of both. We will need a new style of substitution called trigonometric substitution which will be discussed in this section.

subsection.title: The Method of Partial Fractions
subsection.p: The method of partial fractions is used to integrate some rational functions. A rational function is a function that can be written as a quotient of polynomials. The goal of partial fractions is to reverse the process of finding a common denominator, so this method works better when the denominator can be factored into smaller degree polynomials. It is an algebraic manipulation tool that can make integrals more manageable. The method of partial fractions will be demonstrated in the solutions of the next examples. A summary of the method of partial fractions and why it helps with evaluating integrals will follow these examples.

solution.p:
Multiplying both sides of this equation by the denominator of the left hand side, (x-2)(x+1), we find that
5x = A(x+1) + B(x-2) .

To find A and B, we will rearrange the right hand side of the equation so that similar terms are grouped.
5x&=Ax+ A + Bx -2B 5x+0&=(A+B)x + (A-2B)
Notice that if this equation is going to hold, then the coefficients for x on each side of the equation need to match, and we need the constant terms on each side of the equation to match. This gives us the following system of equations: 5=A+B \, \text{ and } \, 0=A-2B We find that A=\frac{10}{3} and B=\frac{5}{3} . Thus, using Equation , we can rewrite the original integral as
\int \frac{5x}{x^2-x-2} \, dx = \int \frac{10/3}{x-2} + \frac{5/3}{x+1} \, dx .

This integral can be evaluated by using the fact that \int \frac{1}{u} \, du =\ln|u| + C and by using substitutions, and hence we find that
\int \frac{5x}{x^2-x-2} \, dx = \frac{10}{3} \ln|x-2| + \frac{5}{3}\ln|x+1| + C .

Multiplying both sides of this equation by the denominator of the left hand side, x(x-1)^2 , we find that
2x^2+5=A(x-1)^2 + B x (x-1) + Cx
To find A , B , and C , we will rearrange the right hand side of the equation so that similar terms are grouped.
2x^2+5&= A(x^2-2x+1) + B(x^2-x) + Cx 2x^2+0x + 5&= (A+B)x^2 + (-2A-B+C)x + A
Like the previous example, we need the coefficients for x^2 to be the same on each side of the equation, the coeffiecients for x to be the same on each side of the equation, and the constant terms to be the same on each side of the equation. Thus, we obtain the system of equations A+B=2 \ , -2A-B+C=0 \ , \text{ and } A=5. We find that A=5 , B=-3 , and C=7 . Thus, using Equation , we can rewrite the original integral as \int \frac{2x^2+5}{x(x-1)^2} \, dx=\int \frac{5}{x}- \frac{3}{x-1} + \frac{7}{(x-1)^2} \, dx
This integral can be evaluated by using the fact that \int \frac{1}{u} \, du =\ln|u|+C and by using appropriate substitutions, and hence we find that
\int \frac{2x^2+5}{x(x-1)^2} \, dx&=\int \frac{5}{x} \, dx - 3 \int \frac{1}{x-1} \, dx + 7 \int (x-2)^{-2} \, dx &=5 \ln|x| -3 \ln|x-1| - 7 (x-1)^{-1} + C

Multiplying both sides of this equation by the denominator of the left hand side, (x^2+2x+3)(x-2) , we find that
3x^2-1= (Ax+B)(x-2)+ C(x^2+2x+3)
To find A , B , and C , we will rearrange the right hand side of the equation so that similar terms are grouped.
3x^2-1&= Ax^2-2Ax + Bx -2B + Cx^2 + 2Cx + 3C 3x^2+0x-1&= (A+C)x^2 + (-2A+B-2C)x + (-2B+3C)
Like the first example, we need the coefficients for x^2 to be the same on each side of the equation, the coeffiecients for x to be the same on each side of the equation, and the constant terms to be the same on each side of the equation. Thus, we obtain the system of equations A+C=3 \ , -2A+B-2C=0 \ , \text{ and } -2B+3C=-1. We find that A=2 , B=2 , and C=1 . Thus, using Equation , we can rewrite the original integral as \int \frac{3x^2-1}{(x^2+2x+3)(x-2)} \, dx=\int \frac{2x+2}{x^2+2x+3} + \frac{1}{x-2} \, dx
This integral can be evaluated by using the fact that \int \frac{1}{u} \, du =\ln|u|+C and by using appropriate substitutions, and hence we find that
\int \frac{3x^2-1}{(x^2+2x+3)(x-2)} \, dx &= \int \frac{2x+2}{x^2+2x+3} \, dx + \int \frac{1}{x-2} \, dx &=\ln|x^2+2x+3| + \ln|x-2|+C

Before decomposing the integrand into partial fractions, we need to perform polynomial long division because the degree of the numerator, 3, is greater than the degree of the denominator, 2. We need to do this because partial fraction decompsition leads to a sum of rational functions where the degree of the numerator is less than the degree of the denominator.

After completing polynomial long division, we find that
\frac{-3x^3+9x^2-9x+7}{-x^2+3x-2} = 3x + \frac{7-3x}{-x^2+3x-2} \, ,
hence, we can change the original integral
\int \frac{-3x^3+9x^2-9x+7}{-x^2+3x-2} \, dx = \int 3x \, dx + \int \frac{7-3x}{-x^2+3x-2} \, dx
We'll proceed by using the method of partial fraction decomposition on the integrand \frac{7-3x}{-x^2+3x-2} .

Multiplying both sides of the equation by the denominator of the left hand side, (x-1)(2-x), we find that 7-3x = A(2-x) + B(x-1)
To find A and B, we will rearrange the right hand side of the equation so that similar terms are grouped.
7-3x&=2A-Ax+Bx-B 7-3x&=(B-A)x+(2A-B)
To make sure the coefficients of x match on each side of the equation and that the constant terms are the same on each side of the equation, we obtain the following system of equations: -3=B-A \text{ and } 7=2A-B
We find that A=4 and B=1 . Thus, using Equation , we can rewrite the original integral as
\int \frac{-3x^3+9x^2-9x+7}{-x^2+3x-2} \, dx &= \int 3x \, dx + \int \frac{7-3x}{-x^2+3x-2} \, dx &= \int 3x \, dx + \int \frac{4}{x-1} + \frac{1}{2-x} \, dx
These integrals can be evaluated by using the antidifferentiation rules from Table and using appropriate substitutions, and hence we find that
\int \frac{-3x^3+9x^2-9x+7}{-x^2+3x-2} \, dx &= \int 3x \, dx + \int \frac{4}{x-1}\, dx + \int \frac{1}{2-x} \, dx &=\frac{3}{2}x^2 + 4\ln|x-1| - \ln|2-x|+C

subsection.p:
These examples have demonstrated how to use the method of partial fraction decomposition in different situations including when the demoninator of a rational function is a product of distinct linear factors, when there is a repeated linear factor in the denominator, when there is an irreducible quadratic factor in the denominator, and when the degree of the numerator is greater than the degree of the denominator.
Method of Partial Fraction Decomposition for a Rational Function R(x)=\frac{P(x)}{Q(x)}
Note: This method works best on rational functions when Q(x) can be factored into linear and irreducible quadratic terms.
If the degree of P(x) is greater than or equal to the degree Q(x) , then perform polynomial long division to calculate \frac{P(x)}{Q(x)}, else move on to the next step. The result gives a new way to write R(x). We know that R(x)= S(x)+ \frac{P_2(x)}{Q(x)} where S(x) is the quotient of the polynomial long division and P_2 (x) is the remainder of the polynomial long division. Now the degree of P_2(x) is less than the degree of Q(x) , so follow the remaining steps to decompose \frac{P_2(x)}{Q(x)} .
If the degree of P(x) is less than the degree of Q(x), then factor Q(x) and add a partial fraction for the decomposition based on the following rules:
For each distinct linear factor (x-c) of Q(x) , add \frac{A}{x-c}.
For each repeated linear factor (x-c)^n of Q(x) where n is a positive whole number, add \frac{A_1}{x-c} + \frac{A_2}{(x-c)^2} + \cdots + \frac{A_n}{(x-c)^n}.
For each irreducible quadratic factor t(x) of Q(x) , add \frac{Ax+B}{t(x)}.
For each repeated irreducible quadratic factor t(x)^n of Q(x) where n is a positive whole number, add \frac{A_1x+B_1}{t(x)} + \frac{A_2x+B_2}{t(x)^2} + \cdots + \frac{A_nx+B_n}{t(x)^n}.

The smaller blocks, or partial fraction terms, that R(x) is broken into often leads to more manageable antidifferentiation. For example if A and k are real numbers, then \int \frac{A}{x-k} \, dx = A \ln |x-k| + C by using the substitution u=x-k . We also know the antiderivative of other common partial fractions like \int \frac{A}{x^2+1} \, dx= \arctan(x) + C .

In many cases, partial fraction decomposition helps the process of finding algebraic antiderivatives; however, there are still some cases where we must find the antiderivative of rational functions like \int \frac{1}{x^2+4x+13} \, dx for which we still need to develop different tools to find an algebraic antiderivative. The topic of Trigonometric Substitutions will allow us to tackle antiderivatives of some ill-behaved functions.

example.p:
For each of the following problems, evaluate the integral by finding the partial fraction decomposition of each integrand.
\int \frac{1}{x^2 - 2x - 3} \, dx
The partial fraction decomposition of the integrand has the form \frac{1}{x^2-2x-3}=\frac{A}{x-3}+\frac{B}{x+1}.
\int \frac{1}{x^2 - 2x - 3} \, dx = \frac{1}{4}\ln|x-3| - \frac{1}{4}\ln|x+1| + C.
To use partial fraction decomposition on the integrand, we'll assume that \frac{1}{x^2-2x-2}=\frac{1}{(x-3)(x+1)}=\frac{A}{x-3}+ \frac{B}{x+1} To solve for A and B, we'll multiply both sides of the equation by the denominator of the left side of the equation and rearrange like the earlier exmaples. We'll have the following sequence of steps:
1&=A(x+1) + B(x-3) 1&=(A+B)x + (A-3B)
We know that A+B=0 \, \text{ and } A-3B=1, so A=1/4 and B=-1/4 . This implies that
\int \frac{1}{x^2 - 2x - 3} \, dx &= \int \frac{1/4}{x-3} - \frac{1/4}{x+1} \, dx & = \frac{1}{4}\ln|x-3| - \frac{1}{4}\ln|x+1| + C.
\int \frac{x^2+1}{x^3 - x^2} \, dx
The partial fraction decomposition of the integrand has the form \frac{x^2+1}{x^3-x^2}=\frac{A}{x} + \frac{B}{x^2} + \frac{C}{x-1}
\int \frac{x^2+1}{x^3 - x^2} \, dx = -\ln|x| + x^{-1} + 2\ln|x-1| + C.
To use partial fraction decomposition on the integrand, we'll assume that \frac{x^2+1}{x^3-x^2}=\frac{x^2+1}{x^2(x-1)}=\frac{A}{x}+ \frac{B}{x^2}+ \frac{C}{x-1} To solve for A , B, and C , we'll multiply both sides of the equation by the denominator of the left side of the equation and rearrange like the earlier exmaples. We'll have the following sequence of steps:
x^2+1&=Ax(x-1) + B(x-1) + Cx^2 x^2+0x+1&=(A+C)x^2 +(B-A)x+ (-B)
We know that A+C=1 \ , B-A=0 \ , \text{ and } -B=1, so A=-1 , B=-1, and C=2. This implies that
\int \frac{x^2+1}{x^3 - x^2} \, dx &= \int\left(-\frac{1}{x} - \frac{1}{x^2} + \frac{2}{x-1} \right) \, dx &= -\ln|x| + x^{-1} + 2\ln|x-1| + C.
\int \frac{x-2}{x^4 + x^2}\, dx
The partial fraction decomposition of the integrand has the form \frac{x-2}{x^4+x^2}=\frac{A}{x} + \frac{B}{x^2} + \frac{Cx+D}{x^2+1}
\int \frac{x-2}{x^4 + x^2}\, dx = \ln|x| + 2x^{-1} - \frac{1}{2} \ln|1+x^2| + 2\arctan(x) + C.
To use partial fraction decomposition on the integrand, we'll assume that \frac{x-2}{x^4+x^2}=\frac{x-2}{x^2(x^2+1)}=\frac{A}{x}+ \frac{B}{x^2} + \frac{Cx+D}{x^2+1} To solve for A , B, C, and D, we'll multiply both sides of the equation by the denominator of the left side of the equation and rearrange like the earlier exmaples. We'll have the following sequence of steps:
x-2&=Ax(x^2+1) + B(x^2+1) + (Cx+D)x^2 x-2&=(A+C)x^3 + (B+D)x^2 + Ax+ B
We know that A+C=0 \ , B+D=0 \ , A=1 \text{ and } B=-2, so A=1 , B=-2 , C=-1, and D=2. Observing that \frac{-x+2}{1+x^2} = \frac{-x}{1+x^2}+\frac{2}{1+x^2}, it now follows that
\int \frac{x-2}{x^4 + x^2}\, dx = \int \frac{1}{x} - \frac{2}{x^2} - \frac{x}{1+x^2} + \frac{2}{1+x^2} \, dx . Noting that \int \frac{x}{1+x^2} \, dx can be evaluated by the u-substitution u=1+x^2, we see that \int \frac{x}{1+x^2} \, dx = \frac{1}{2} \ln(1+x^2) + C. Thus
\int \frac{x-2}{x^4 + x^2}\, dx &= \int \frac{1}{x} - \frac{2}{x^2} - \frac{x}{1+x^2} + \frac{2}{1+x^2} \, dx &= \ln|x| + 2x^{-1} - \frac{1}{2} \ln(1+x^2) + 2\arctan(x) + C.
\int \frac{4x^2+x}{2x^2+x-1} \, dx
First, use polynomial long division then the partial fraction decomposition of the remainder will have the form \frac{A}{2x-1}+\frac{B}{x+1}.
\int \frac{4x^2+x}{2x^2+x-1} \, dx=2x + \frac{1}{2} \ln|2x-1|-\ln|x+1|+C
First, use polynomial long division since the degree of the numerator is the same as the degree of the denominator. We'll find that \frac{4x^2+x}{2x^2+x-1} = 2 + \frac{2-x}{2x^2+x-1}. To use partial fraction decomposition on the remainder, we'll assume that \frac{2-x}{2x^2+x-1}=\frac{2-x}{(2x-1)(x+1)}=\frac{A}{2x-1}+ \frac{B}{x+1} To solve for A and B, we'll multiply both sides of the equation by the denominator of the left side of the equation and rearrange like the earlier exmaples. We'll have the following sequence of steps:
2-x&=A(x+1) + B(2x-1) 2-x&=(A+2B)x + (A-B)
We know that A+2B=-1 \, \text{ and } A-B=2, so A=1 and B=-1. This implies that
\int \frac{4x^2+x}{2x^2+x-1} \, dx &= \int\left(2 + \frac{1}{2x-1} - \frac{1}{x+1} \right) \, dx &= 2x + \frac{1}{2}\ln|2x-1|-\ln|x+1| + C.

subsection.title: Trigonometric Substitutions
subsection.p: In the partial fraction section, we saw that this algebraic tool allowed us to break rational functions into manageable chunks, but we didn't yet have the right tool to handle indefinite integrals like \int \frac{1}{x^2+4x+13} \, dx. In Example , we complete the square to put the integrand in the form \frac{1}{(x+2)^2 + 9} . Now, the integrand looks similar to the derivative of \arctan(x+2) , but we can see that this is not correct antiderivative since \frac{d}{dx} [\arctan(x+2)]=\frac{1}{(x+2)^2+1}. We'll introduce a new substitution style that introduces trigonometric functions so that we can leverage Pythagoren's Identity and a modified version of Pythagorean's Identity. The new tools we are introducing to find algebraic antiderivatives are the substitutions x=\sin(\theta) and x=\tan(\theta) and variations on these substitututions.

li.p: Modified Pythagorean's Identity: (It can be found by starting with Pythagorean's Identity then dividing by \cos^2(\theta) on both sides of the equation) \tan^2(\theta) + 1=\sec^2(\theta)

subsection.p:
First, let's look at the substitution x=\sin(\theta) where -\frac{\pi}{2}\leq \theta \leq \frac{\pi}{2} Example will show why we need these bounds on \theta to see how it can be used to find the indefinite integral \int \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^2}} \, dx.
Use the substitution x=\sin(\theta) where -\frac{\pi}{2} \leq \theta \leq \frac{\pi}{2} to find the general antiderivative \int \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}\, dx.
When using the substitution x=\sin(\theta) where -\frac{\pi}{2} \leq \theta \leq \frac{\pi}{2} , we are regarding x as a function of \theta . The goal is to change the integrand to contain trigonometric functions so that Pythagorean's Identity can be used. To do this, the integral will be changed to be in terms of the variable \theta. With this in mind, both x and dx will need to be changed. Starting from x=\sin(\theta) , take the derivative with respect to \theta to find that \frac{dx}{d\theta}=\cos(\theta) . In other words, dx=\cos(\theta) \, d\theta . Now, change the original integral to be in terms of the variable \theta : \int\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}\, dx=\int \frac{\cos(\theta)}{\sqrt{1-\sin^2(\theta)}} \, d\theta Use Pythagorean's Identity, 1-\sin^2(\theta)=\cos^2(\theta) to simplify the denominator of the integrand: \int \frac{\cos(\theta)}{\sqrt{1-\sin^2(\theta)}} \, d\theta = \int\frac{\cos(\theta)}{\sqrt{\cos^2(\theta)}} \, d \theta. Now we need to use the assumption that -\frac{\pi}{2} \leq \theta \leq \frac{\pi}{2}. In general, \sqrt{\cos^2(\theta)}=|\cos(\theta)|, but \cos(\theta)\geq 0 on the interval -\frac{\pi}{2} \leq \theta \leq \frac{\pi}{2}. Thus, |\cos(\theta)|=\cos(\theta) if -\frac{\pi}{2} \leq \theta \leq \frac{\pi}{2} . The denominator can now be further simplified, and the remaining steps lead to a familar integral:
\int\frac{\cos(\theta)}{\sqrt{\cos^2(\theta)}} \, d\theta \amp = \int\frac{\cos(\theta)}{|\cos(\theta)|} \, d\theta \amp =\int\frac{\cos(\theta)}{\cos(\theta)} \, d\theta \amp =\int 1 \, d\theta \amp =\theta + C
While we have computed an antiderivative successfully, we aren't quite done yet because the answer is not written in terms of the original variable x . Rearrange the substitution equation x=\sin(\theta) to find that \theta=\arcsin(x) and use this to turn \theta back into a function of x . Therefore, \int\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^2}} \, dx= \arcsin(x) + C
From now on, we'll usually omit the explanation that \sqrt{\cos^2(\theta)}=|\cos(\theta)|=\cos(\theta) since we additionally assume that -\frac{\pi}{2} \leq \theta \leq \frac{\pi}{2} in order to force \cos(\theta) \geq 0 . It is still incredibly important so that the calculation of the antiderivative is seamless, but since we always assume that -\frac{\pi}{2} \leq \theta \leq \frac{\pi}{2} the same reasoning always applies.

The style of substitution that was demonstrated in the previous example can be extended to help find more algebraic antiderivatives especially when the integrand contains a^2-u^2 where a is a real number and u is a variable and other methods like u-substitution and partial fractions have failed. The changes that will be made to the substitution are necessary so that Pythagorean's Identity can still be applied. The following examples will explore exactly what alterations should be made to the substitution x=\sin(\theta) .
Use a trigonometric substitution to evaluate \int \frac{1}{\sqrt{16-x^2}} \, dx
Use the substitution x=4\sin(\theta) with -\frac{\pi}{2} \leq \theta \leq \frac{\pi}{2} . How does including the factor of 4 affect our ability to use Pythagorean's Identity?
\int \frac{1}{\sqrt{16-x^2}} \, dx= \arcsin\left(\frac{x}{4}\right) + C
Use the substitution x=4\sin(\theta) with -\frac{\pi}{2} \leq \theta \leq \frac{\pi}{2} . Then x^2=16\sin^2(\theta) and dx=4\cos(\theta) d\theta . This implies that
\int \frac{1}{\sqrt{16-x^2}} \, dx \amp = \int \frac{4\cos(\theta)}{\sqrt{16-16\sin^2(\theta)}} \, d\theta \amp = \int \frac{4\cos(\theta)}{\sqrt{16(1-\sin^2(\theta))}} \, d\theta \amp = \int \frac{4\cos(\theta)}{\sqrt{16\cos^2(\theta)}} \, d\theta \amp = \int \frac{4\cos(\theta)}{4\cos(\theta)} \, d\theta \amp = \int 1 \, d\theta \amp = \theta + C \amp = \arcsin\left(\frac{x}{4}\right) + C
It's possible to find the answer to part (a) by using some algebra, a u-sub, and the antidifferentiation rule \int \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-u^2}} \, du =\arcsin(u) + C. Without using a trigonometric substitution, evaluate \int \frac{1}{\sqrt{16-x^2}} \, dx
Factor out 16 from the expression inside the square root, so \sqrt{16-x^2}=\sqrt{16(1-\frac{x^2}{16})}=\sqrt{16(1-\frac{x^2}{4^2})}.
\int \frac{1}{\sqrt{16-x^2}} \, dx= \arcsin\left(\frac{x}{4}\right) + C
We'll factor out 16 from the expression inside the square root and continue to rearrange the denominator in preparation of using a substitution:
\int \frac{1}{\sqrt{16-x^2}} \, dx \amp = \int \frac{1}{\sqrt{16(1-\frac{x^2}{16})}} \, dx \amp = \int \frac{1}{\sqrt{16(1-\frac{x^2}{4^2})}} \, dx \amp = \int \frac{1}{\sqrt{16(1-\frac{x^2}{4^2})}} \, dx \amp =\int \frac{1}{4\sqrt{1-(x/4)^2}} \, dx
Use the substitution u=\frac{x}{4} , du= \frac{1}{4} \, dx:
\int \frac{1}{4\sqrt{1-(x/4)^2}} \, dx \amp= \int\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-u^2}} \, du \amp= \arcsin(u) + C \amp= \arcsin\left(\frac{x}{4} \right) + C
Use a trigonometric substitution to find the indefinite integral \int \frac{1}{\sqrt{9-4x^2}} \, dx.
Notice that \sqrt{9-4x^2}=\sqrt{9-(2x)^2}, so we'll want to replace 2x by an appropriate trigonometric function.
\int \frac{1}{\sqrt{9-4x^2}} \, dx=\frac{1}{2} \arcsin \left(\frac{2x}{3}\right) + C
Compared to the first example, where the substitution x=\sin(\theta) worked, we'll need to make two adjustments so that we can still use Pythagoren's Identity. Since \sqrt{9-4x^2}=\sqrt{9-(2x)^2}, we'll want to substitute 2x=3\sin(\theta) so that we can factor out the 9 and obtain the expression 1-\sin^2(\theta) . Assuming 2x=3\sin(\theta) then (2x)^2=9 \sin^2(\theta) and 2 dx=3 \cos(\theta)d\theta.
\int \frac{1}{\sqrt{9-4x^2}} \, dx \amp = \int \frac{1}{\sqrt{9-(2x)^2}} \, dx \amp = \int \frac{1}{\sqrt{9-(2x)^2}} \, dx \amp = \int \frac{(3/2)\cos(\theta)}{\sqrt{9-9\sin^2(\theta)}} \, d\theta \amp = \frac{3}{2}\int \frac{\cos(\theta)}{\sqrt{9(1-\sin^2(\theta))}} \, d\theta \amp = \frac{3}{2}\int \frac{\cos(\theta)}{3\sqrt{\cos^2(\theta)}} \, d\theta \amp = \frac{3}{2}\int \frac{\cos(\theta)}{3\cos(\theta)} \, d\theta \amp = \frac{3}{6}\int 1 \, d\theta \amp = \frac{1}{2}\theta+ C \
We can solve for \theta in our substitution equation to find that the antiderivative is: \int \frac{1}{\sqrt{9-4x^2}} \, dx=\frac{1}{2} \arcsin\left(\frac{2x}{3} \right) + C
Find the antiderivative \int \frac{9}{(9-x^2)^{3/2}} \, dx
Use the substitution x=3\sin(\theta) and treat (9-x^2)^{3/2} as ((9-x^2)^{1/2})^3 .
\int \frac{9}{(9-x^2)^{3/2}} \, dx=\dfrac{x}{9-x^2} + C
Use the substitution x=3\sin(\theta) . Then x^2=9\sin^2(\theta) and dx=3\cos(\theta) d\theta. As stated in the hint, we'll use that (9-x^2)^{3/2}=((9-x^2)^{1/2})^3 and simplify the inner most set of parentheses before cubing.
\int \frac{9}{(9-x^2)^{3/2}} \, dx \amp = \int \frac{9\cdot 3\cos(\theta)}{(9-9\sin^2(\theta))^{3/2}} \, d\theta \amp = 27\int \frac{\cos(\theta)}{(9(1-\sin^2(\theta)))^{3/2}} \, d\theta \amp = 27\int \frac{\cos(\theta)}{9^{3/2}((1-\sin^2(\theta))^{1/2})^3} \, d\theta \amp = \frac{27}{27}\int \frac{\cos(\theta)}{((\cos^2(\theta))^{1/2})^3} \, d\theta \amp =\int \frac{\cos(\theta)}{(\cos(\theta))^3} \, d\theta \amp =\int \frac{1}{\cos^2(\theta)} \, d\theta \amp = \tan(\theta) + C
When we solve for \theta and replace it with a function of x , we obtain \int \frac{9}{(9-x^2)^{3/2}} \, dx = \tan(\arcsin(x/3)) + C . In other words, the general antiderivative is the tangent of the angle whose sine is \frac{x}{3} . To simplify this expression, we can look at a right triangle that has \theta as one of its angles and use some trigonometry. Since \sin(\theta) = \frac{x}{3} , we'll assume that the hypotenuse has length 3 and the side opposite the angle \theta has length x . The missing side length is found by using Pythagorean's Theorem. Then using this right triangle, we find that \tan(\theta)=\frac{x}{\sqrt{9-x^2}} . Therefore, \int \frac{9}{(9-x^2)^{3/2}} \, dx = \frac{x}{\sqrt{9-x^2}} + C
A right triangle corresponding to \sin(\theta)=\frac{x}{3}

assemblage.title: Trigonometric Substitution: u=a\sin(\theta)
assemblage.p: The substitution u=a\sin(\theta) where u is some function of x , a is a real number, and -\frac{\pi}{2} \leq \theta \leq \frac{\pi}{2} is often helpful when the integrand contains an expression of the form a^2-u^2 . When this substitution is used, then u^2=a^2\sin^2(\theta) and after factoring out a^2 , Pythagorean's Identity 1-\sin^2(\theta)=\cos^2(\theta) can be used to simplify part of the integrand: a^2-u^2=a^2-a^2\sin^2(\theta)=a^2(1-\sin^2(\theta))=a^2\cos^2(\theta) .
Since we assumed -\frac{\pi}{2} \leq \theta \leq \frac{\pi}{2} , then \cos (\theta) \geq 0 . This implies that \sqrt{\cos^2(\theta)}=|\cos(\theta)|=\cos(\theta) .

subsection.p:
Another important trigonometric substitution is x=\tan(\theta) where -\frac{\pi}{2} < \theta < \frac{\pi}{2} Example TBA shows why we need these assumptions . This substitution can be used to show that \int \frac{1}{1+x^2} \, dx= \arctan(x) + C .
Use the trigonometric substitution x=\tan(\theta) to find the antiderivative \int \frac{1}{1+x^2} \, dx .
When using the substitution x=\tan(\theta) where -\frac{\pi}{2} < \theta < \frac{\pi}{2} , we are regarding x as a function of \theta . The goal is to change the integrand to contain trigonometric functions so that a modified version of Pythagorean's Identity can be used. The version of Pythagorean's Identity we will use when simplifying after a tangent substitution is \tan^2(\theta) + 1 =\sec^2(\theta) . To achieve this goal, the integral will be changed to be in terms of the variable \theta. With this in mind, both x and dx will need to be changed. Starting from x=\tan(\theta) , take the derivative with respect to \theta to find that \frac{dx}{d\theta}=\sec^2(\theta) . In other words, dx=\sec^2(\theta) \, d\theta . Now, change the original integral to be in terms of the variable \theta : \int\frac{1}{1+x^2}\, dx=\int \frac{\sec^2(\theta)}{1+\tan^2(\theta)} \, d\theta Use a modified version of Pythagorean's Identity, 1+\tan^2(\theta)=\sec^2(\theta) to simplify the denominator of the integrand: \int \frac{\sec^2(\theta)}{1+\tan^2(\theta)} \, d\theta = \int\frac{\sec^2(\theta)}{\sec^2(\theta)} \, d \theta. The integrand can now be further simplified, and the remaining steps lead to a familar antiderivative:
\int\frac{\sec^2(\theta)}{\sec^2(\theta)} \, d \theta&= \int 1 \, d \theta &=\theta + C
While we have computed an antiderivative successfully, we aren't quite done yet because the answer is not written in terms of the original variable x . Rearrange the substitution equation x=\tan(\theta) to find that \theta=\arctan(x) and use this to turn \theta back into a function of x . Therefore, \int\frac{1}{1+x^2} \, dx= \arctan(x) + C
The style of substitution that was demonstrated in the previous example can be extended to help find more algebraic antiderivatives especially when the integrand contains a^2+u^2 where a is a real number and u is a variable. The changes that will be made to the substitution are necessary so that a modified Pythagorean's Identity can still be applied. The following examples will explore exactly what alterations should be made to the substitution x=\tan(\theta).
Use a trigonometric substitution to find the antiderivative \int \frac{1}{16 + x^2} \, dx .
Try the substitution x=4\tan(\theta) .
\int \frac{1}{16 + x^2} \, dx=\frac{1}{4}\arctan\left(\frac{x}{4} \right) + C
The denominator of the integrand can be written as 4^2 + x^2 which is why we pick the substitution x=4\tan(\theta) . The extra factor of 4 in front of \tan(\theta) is needed to use the modified Pythagorean's Identity in the process of simplifying the integrand. Since x=4\tan(\theta) , then x^2=16\tan^2(\theta) and dx=4\sec^2(\theta) d\theta. This implies that
\int \frac{1}{16 + x^2} \, dx &= \int \frac{4\sec^2(\theta)}{16 + 16\tan^2(\theta)} \, d \theta &= 4\int \frac{\sec^2(\theta)}{16(1+\tan^2(\theta))} \, d\theta &= \frac{4}{16}\int \frac{\sec^2(\theta)}{\sec^2(\theta)} \, d\theta &= \frac{1}{4}\int 1 \, d\theta &= \frac{1}{4} \theta + C &= \frac{1}{4} \arctan\left(\frac{x}{4} \right) + C
It's possible to find the answer to part (a) by using some algebra, a u-sub, and the antidifferentiation rule \int \frac{1}{1+u^2} \, du=\arctan(u) + C . Without using a trigonometric substitution, find the integral \int \frac{1}{16 + x^2} \, dx .
Factor out 16 from the denominator; in other words, 16+x^2=16(1+x^2/16)
\int \frac{1}{16 + x^2} \, dx=\frac{1}{4}\arctan\left(\frac{x}{4} \right) + C
Factor out 16 from the denominator and rearrange it so that it is in the form a^2 + u^2 :
\int \frac{1}{16+x^2} \, dx &= \frac{1}{16} \int \frac{1}{1+x^2/16} \, dx &= \frac{1}{16} \int \frac{1}{1+(x/4)^2} \, dx
Now, we can use a substitution and the antidifferentiation rule \int \frac{1}{1+u^2} \, du=\arctan(u) + C . Let u=\frac{x}{4}, then du=\frac{dx}{4} and 4 du=dx.
\frac{1}{16} \int \frac{1}{1+(x/4)^2} \, dx &= \frac{1}{16} \int \frac{4}{1+u^2} \, du &= \frac{4}{16} \arctan(u) + C &=\frac{1}{4} \arctan(x/4) + C
In the following example, we'll see why it is important that we restrict \theta to be in the interval -\frac{\pi}{2} < \theta < \frac{\pi}{2} when we use a tangent substitution.
Use a trigonometric substitution to find the integral \int \frac{3x}{\sqrt{25+9x^2}} \, dx .
The expression 25 + 9x^2 can be rewritten as 5^2+(3x)^2 so that it looks like u^2+a^2. Try the substitution 3x=5\tan(\theta) .
\int \frac{3x}{\sqrt{25+9x^2}} \, dx =\frac{1}{3} \sqrt{9x^2+25} + C
The expression 25 + 9x^2 can be rewritten as 5^2+(3x)^2 so that it looks like u^2+a^2. The substitution 3x=5\tan(\theta) will allow us to use the modified Pythagorean Identity. Then (3x)^2=25\tan^2(\theta) and dx=\frac{5}{3} \sec^2(\theta) d\theta . The original integral can be transformed using this substitution:
\int \frac{3x}{\sqrt{25+9x^2}} \, dx &= \frac{5}{3}\int \frac{5\tan(\theta)\sec^2(\theta)}{\sqrt{25+25\tan^2(\theta)}} \, d\theta &= \frac{25}{3}\int \frac{\tan(\theta)\sec^2(\theta)}{\sqrt{25(1+\tan^2(\theta)}} \, d\theta &= \frac{25}{3}\int \frac{\tan(\theta)\sec^2(\theta)}{\sqrt{25\sec^2(\theta)}} \, d\theta &= \frac{25}{3}\int \frac{\tan(\theta)\sec^2(\theta)}{\sqrt{25}\sqrt{\sec^2(\theta)}} \, d\theta
We must be careful at this step when we simplify \sqrt{\sec^2(\theta)}. Because we chose -\frac{\pi}{2} < \theta < \frac{\pi}{2} , then \sec^2(\theta) \geq 1 \geq 0 . Notice that if we had picked a different interval for \theta , \sec(\theta) could be negative and then we would have to introduce an absolute value in order for the square root to be defined. Since we know \sec^2(\theta) \geq 1\geq 0 on the interval of \theta we care about then \sqrt{\sec^2(\theta)}=\sec(\theta). Therefore, the integral simplifies further:
\frac{25}{3}\int \frac{\tan(\theta)\sec^2(\theta)}{\sqrt{25}\sqrt{\sec^2(\theta)}} \, d\theta &= \frac{5}{3} \int \frac{\tan(\theta) \sec^2(\theta) }{\sec(\theta)} \, d \theta &= \frac{5}{3} \int \tan(\theta)\sec(\theta) \, d \theta &=\frac{5}{3} \sec(\theta) + C &= \frac{5}{3} \sec\left(\arctan\left(\frac{3x}{5} \right)\right) + C
This answer can be simplified to a more recognizable form by using a right triangle with angle \theta and \tan(\theta)=\frac{3x}{5} , and finding \sec(\theta) by using the triangle.
A right triangle corresponding to \tan(\theta)=\frac{3x}{5}
Thus
\int \frac{3x}{\sqrt{25+9x^2}} \, dx &=\frac{5}{3} \sec\left(\arctan\left(\frac{3x}{5} \right)\right) + C &= \frac{5}{3} \cdot \frac{\sqrt{9x^2+25}}{5} + C &=\frac{1}{3} \sqrt{9x^2+25} + C
A trigonometric substitution was not necessary to find the antiderivative in part (a). In fact, only a standard u -subsitution was needed. Verify the answer from part (a) using the method of u-substitution.
The expressions 3x and 9x^2 + 25 are nearly a function-derivative pair.
\int \frac{3x}{\sqrt{25+9x^2}} \, dx =\frac{1}{3} \sqrt{9x^2+25} + C
Use the substitution u=9x^2 + 25 with du=18x dx to change the original integral.
\int \frac{3x}{\sqrt{25+9x^2}} \, dx &= \frac{1}{6} \int u^{-1/2} \, du &= \frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{u^{1/2}}{1/2} + C &= \frac{1}{3} \sqrt{9x^2+25} + C
After using partial fraction decomposition, one of the partial fractions could have an irreducible quadratic in the denominator and a constant term in the numerator. For example, we might need to find the integral \int \frac{1}{x^2+4x+13} \, dx. We cannot use u -substitution since we would need a linear term in the numerator, and no other method of integration seems to work. If we complete the square in the denominator to recognize it as u^2+a^2 where u is a variable term and a is a real number, then a tangent substitution becomes a very promising method of integration.
Find the integral \int \frac{1}{x^2+4x+13} \, dx.
Completing the square in the denominator gives \frac{1}{x^2+4x+13}=\frac{1}{(x+2)^2 + 9}
\int \frac{1}{x^2+4x+13} \, dx= \frac{1}{3} \arctan\left(\frac{x+2}{3} \right) + C
To complete the square in the denominator, we need to add and substract 4 so that we can factor a portion of the expression into a linear term that is squared: \frac{1}{x^2+4x+13}=\frac{1}{x^2+4x+4-4+13}=\frac{1}{(x+2)^2+9} For more details on completing the square, go to INSERT REFERENCE TO PRECALC BOOK HERE :). Now, use the u -substitution u=x+2 \ , du=dx . \int \frac{1}{(x+2)^2+9} \, dx = \int \frac{1}{u^2+9} \, du Use the tangent subsitutionWe could also factor out 9 from the denominator and use a substitution with w=\frac{x+2}{3} as demonstrated in Example . u=3\tan(\theta) , so u^2=9\tan^2(\theta) and du=3\sec^2(\theta) \, d\theta .
\int \frac{1}{u^2+9} \, du&= \int \frac{3\sec^2(\theta)}{9\tan^2(\theta) +9 }\, d \theta &= 3\int \frac{\sec^2(\theta)}{9(\tan^2(\theta) +1) }\, d \theta &= \frac{3}{9}\int \frac{\sec^2(\theta)}{\sec^2(\theta) }\, d \theta &= \frac{1}{3}\int 1 \, d \theta &= \frac{1}{3} \theta + C &= \frac{1}{3} \arctan\left(\frac{u}{3} \right) + C &= \frac{1}{3} \arctan\left(\frac{x+2}{3} \right) + C

assemblage.title: Trigonometric Substitution: u=a\tan(\theta)
assemblage.p: The substitution u=a\tan(\theta) where u is some function of x , a is a real number, and -\frac{\pi}{2} < \theta < \frac{\pi}{2} is often helpful when the integrand contains an expression of the form a^2+u^2 . When this substitution is used, then u^2=a^2\tan^2(\theta) and after factoring out a^2 , a modified Pythagorean's Identity 1+\tan^2(\theta)=\sec^2(\theta) can be used to simplify part of the integrand: a^2+u^2=a^2+a^2\tan^2(\theta)=a^2(1+\tan^2(\theta))=a^2\sec^2(\theta) .
Since we assumed -\frac{\pi}{2} < \theta < \frac{\pi}{2} , then \sec (\theta) \geq 1\geq 0 . This implies that \sqrt{\sec^2(\theta)}=|\sec(\theta)|=\sec(\theta) .
